strip.synopsis: The plant Wally has been feeding coffee dregs grows enormous.

strip.subject: Dating
strip.synopsis: Dilbert opts for him and his date to be seated in the "loud guy" section.

strip.subject: Philosophy
strip.synopsis: Asok wonders about his purpose in life. Wally has it figured out.

strip.subject: Office Politics
strip.synopsis: Wally tries to blackmail Dilbert by threatening to give him a bad peer review.

strip.subject: Tech Support
strip.synopsis: Right before lunch, Dogbert's tech support service requires a password.

strip.subject: Management
strip.synopsis: The Boss asks Asok to attend the technology steering committee meeting in his place.

strip.subject: Secretary
strip.synopsis: Carol doesn't like the way Dilbert asked for help, so she ignores him.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Famous artist "Dogberto" explains his plans for decorating the lobby.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: "Dogberto" explains his plans for decorating the courtyard.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: An Elbonian sells the Boss on having his product manufactured in Elbonia.

strip.subject: Secretary
strip.synopsis: Carol brings her daughter to work so she can learn about working in a corporate environment.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: Dilbert shows the Boss the prototype from the Elbonian factory.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: Dilbert had a conference call with the Elbonians at 3am.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: The Elbonian MP3 player prototype will need a lot of marketing.

strip.subject: Marketing
strip.synopsis: The Boss examines Dogbert's marketing resume.

strip.subject: Marketing
strip.synopsis: Dogbert explains how to market their new MP3 player.

strip.subject: Marketing
strip.synopsis: Dogbert explains how to make their new MP3 player less scary.

strip.subject: Interview
strip.synopsis: Catbert asks the Boss to make sure a candidate isn't too old.

strip.subject: Policy
strip.synopsis: Company policy does not allow space heaters in cubicles.
strip.note: Scott reported some newspapers changed the punchline from "it keeps Uranus warm" to "it keeps Venus warm".

strip.subject: Downsizing
strip.saga: Asok is mistakenly left in the desert
strip.synopsis: The Boss sends Ted on a "team-building" exercise.

strip.subject: Downsizing
strip.synopsis: The Boss mistakenly sends Asok on a "team-building" exercise instead of Ted.

strip.subject: Nature
strip.synopsis: Asok knows how to survive in the desert.

strip.subject: Management
strip.synopsis: Asok returns from his ordeal in the desert and he is mad.

strip.subject: Vacation
strip.synopsis: Wally doubles the length of his vacation when the Boss doesn't realise he was gone.

strip.subject: Sales
strip.synopsis: Wally inadvertently helps the competition make a sale.

strip.subject: Office Politics
strip.synopsis: The Boss asks Alice to be less productive.

strip.subject: Office Politics
strip.synopsis: The Boss hires a new employee so he can get an automatic promotion.

strip.subject: Technology
strip.synopsis: Dilbert's Mom's computer asks whether or not she wants to update her security software.

strip.subject: Contractor
strip.saga: Dangling the carrot in front of a contract employee
strip.synopsis: The Boss brings the new hire on as a contract employee while "dangling the carrot" of becoming a regular employee.

strip.subject: Contractor
strip.synopsis: The Boss threatens the new contractor with his firing finger.

strip.subject: Contractor
strip.synopsis: The new contractor explains his dream is to become a regular employee.

strip.subject: Leadership
strip.synopsis: Dilbert's chair breaks and the Boss tells him to turn it over and continue using it.

strip.subject: Personality
strip.synopsis: A co-worker asks Dilbert his opinion on her project plan.

strip.subject: Work Avoidance
strip.synopsis: A co-worker asks Wally for a second opinion on her project plan.

strip.subject: Engineer
strip.synopsis: A co-worker asks Alice for a third opinion on her project plan.

strip.subject: Management
strip.synopsis: A co-worker complains to the Boss the others don't like her project plan.

strip.subject: Health
strip.synopsis: Dilbert complains his cubicle is inhibiting brain growth.

strip.subject: Personality
strip.synopsis: Topper claims he carried over so much vacation time they had to create a new month named for him.

strip.subject: Office Politics
strip.synopsis: The Boss gets "minimised".

strip.subject: Travel
strip.synopsis: The car rental place has no cars left for Dilbert.

strip.subject: Travel
strip.synopsis: Dilbert has to run to a meeting.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dogbert plans to build his own country on the ocean using barges.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Vijay funds Dogbert's plan to build an ocean city on barges.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dogbert is recruiting a couple for his "Barge City".

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dogbert welcomes the first residents of his "Barge City".

strip.subject: Training
strip.synopsis: Wally inadvertently admits to several indiscretions before the Boss can finish what he's saying.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dilbert wants to borrow money from Dogbert to open his own business.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dogbert explains to Ratbert how he made a billion dollars in shady real estate deals.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Bono mistakes Ratbert for Dogbert and tries to get him to donate his billions of dollars to charity.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.saga: Dogbert buys the Company and fires Dilbert
strip.synopsis: Dogbert buys Dilbert's company and fires him.

strip.subject: Downsizing
strip.synopsis: Dilbert goes online looking for a great job and finds an opening for a condiment.

strip.subject: Downsizing
strip.synopsis: Dilbert doesn't get hired because he solved their problem during the interview.

strip.subject: Ethics
strip.synopsis: Wally from the future travels back in time to refresh his cup of coffee.

strip.subject: Society
strip.synopsis: Dilbert talks to the Garbageman about employment and love.

strip.subject: Dating
strip.synopsis: Dilbert has a blind date with a woman who knows how to use Photoshop.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dilbert wonders why ultra-wealthy Dogbert still lives with him.

strip.subject: Interview
strip.synopsis: Dilbert visits a career counsellor who labels him a loser.

strip.subject: Business
strip.saga: Dilbert invents a new search engine
strip.synopsis: Dilbert starts a high tech company in the garage.

strip.subject: Technology
strip.synopsis: Dilbert invents a search engine and dating service.

strip.subject: Office Politics
strip.synopsis: Alice threatens to quit, but decides to stay when the Boss offers her a raise.

strip.subject: Law
strip.synopsis: Dilbert goes to a patent lawyer to patent his search engine algorithm.

strip.subject: Technology
strip.synopsis: Dilbert explains he's not afraid of Google.

strip.subject: Technology
strip.synopsis: The Google founders discuss how to kill Dilbert without being evil.

strip.subject: Technology
strip.synopsis: Dogbert activates his space defence shield to protect their house.

strip.subject: Entrepreneur
strip.synopsis: Vijay funds Dilbert's start-up company.

strip.subject: Law
strip.synopsis: Dilbert's old company launches a lawyer to talk to him about his patent.

strip.subject: Meeting
strip.synopsis: In order to be productive, work is getting done during the Boss's meeting.

strip.subject: Law
strip.synopsis: The Boss claims Dilbert thought up the search engine before they fired him, therefore it's theirs.

strip.subject: Law
strip.synopsis: A lawyer explains the details of the non-compete agreement Dilbert had signed when he worked for the company.

strip.subject: Personnel
strip.synopsis: Dilbert demands his old job back.

strip.subject: Management
strip.saga: The Boss, master of non-monetary compensation
strip.synopsis: The Boss gives Carol the new office supply catalogue to peruse instead of a raise.

strip.subject: Benefits
strip.synopsis: The Boss rewards Alice by letting her punch Ken in marketing as hard as she wants.

strip.subject: Benefits
strip.synopsis: The Boss rewards Asok by offering to listen to a boring story about his life.

strip.subject: Retail
strip.synopsis: Dilbert refuses to accept a game card that has a chance of winning free groceries.

strip.subject: Character
strip.synopsis: The Boss introduces Lou Serdecisions to Dilbert. Lou asks Dilbert to cover for him during the project kickoff meeting.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.saga: The outsourcing of Asok's job to India
strip.synopsis: The Boss tells Asok his job is being outsourced to India.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: Asok tells Wally about his job being outsourced to India.

strip.subject: Outsourcing
strip.synopsis: Asok's job gets outsourced right back to him.

strip.subject: Management
strip.synopsis: Alice presents the results of her cost-benefit study to the product review committee.

strip.subject: Management
strip.synopsis: The Boss misunderstands what the phrase "government mandate" means.

strip.subject: Leadership
strip.synopsis: The Boss's brain shuts down for the afternoon, so he has to resort to some generic leadership.

strip.subject: Dogbert-Schemes
strip.synopsis: Dogbert claims his software is idiot-proof.

strip.subject: Personal
strip.synopsis: Dilbert has been selected for a random drug test, but he has a shy bladder.

strip.subject: Personal
strip.synopsis: Dilbert tries to explain his shy bladder to the Boss.
Catbert asks for a urine sample. Dilbert suggests a hair sample instead.
Patty distorts Dilbert's statement about receiving a proposal from a vendor into Dilbert loves the new vendor.
Dilbert asks Patty to relay to the project team the schedule is being pushed back by a week.
A co-worker asks Dilbert to buy a candy bar from her daughter's fund raiser.
An old person doesn't believe in using Blackberries.
Satan's vendor describes the benefits of their technology and gives away t-shirts.
Satan's vendor will send the engineers on a free training course on an island retreat.
Satan's vendor brags to Alice there's nothing she can do about raised prices and delayed promises.
The Boss wants to know why a project failed. Dilbert says management discourages opinions.
The Boss installs his management listening catheter before hearing Dilbert's suggestion.
The Boss criticises Dilbert for his project coming in at 10% over budget even though it was exactly what Dilbert had estimated.
Smokin' Jim can't contain his urge and lights up.
Smokin' Jim tells Alice about his attention deficit disorder.
The Boss orders Dilbert to work on the weekend. Dilbert says there's nothing to do.
Dilbert asks the Boss which of the thirty projects he remembers assigning to Dilbert.
A trash collector freaks out when Dilbert puts his gum in the trash instead of the recycle bin.
Bulldozer Betty asks Asok to drop everything. So he drops his clothes.
strip.note: The original version showed Asok's butt as he shivered in the hallway. For the final version, Scott added underpants. Panels were published on Scott's blog.

strip.synopsis: Dogbert welcomes everyone to his accelerated sales training course.
The Boss asks Dilbert to bring him up to speed before the meeting.
Dogbert shows Dilbert his future best-selling book - part fake autobiography and part plagiarism.
Dogbert asks Dilbert to appear on the Oprah show in his place to talk about his new book.
An employee says she's quitting because she wants to kill the Boss.
Wally asks for a bonus just like the CEO's bonus.
Stinky Pete arrives to help Alice with her technical problem.
A new employee, Amber Dextrous, is introduced to Dilbert. She can do two things at the same time.
Stinky Pete describes his trip to work, eating an onion sandwich and rolling in a sewage spill.
Carol says she can no longer work with Dilbert because of something he said about her.
Carol welcomes attendees to a meeting of insane chicks.
At a meeting of insane chicks, someone complains about her boyfriend.
Catbert discovers embellishments on the Boss's resume.
After discovering the Boss lied on his resume, the Boss goes to see the VP of HR.
The Boss asks Dilbert to do a project in his spare time. Dilbert doesn't know what spare time means.
An Elbonian says they discovered the mud in Elbonia is caused by an abundance of oil and coal near the surface.
The Boss asks Dilbert to write a business case lobby the government to attack Elbonia.
Dogbert wants to be hired as a lobbyist to convince Switzerland to attack Elbonia.
Dogbert the lobbyist says he'll get the government to include industrial waste in the food pyramid.
Dogbert bribes a congressman to vote for tax breaks for Dogbert's client.
Dogbert tells an Elbonian governments will attack his country and liberate him and his oil.
Wally agrees to look into getting technical specifications for a co-worker. The co-worker wants the specifications.
Wally says he's late to the meeting because he was stuck behind some slow walkers.
Asok goes to a meeting instead of the Boss. The other people wanted the Boss's input instead.
Wally asks the Boss what type of decision-making he'll use today, authoritative, consultative voting or consensus.
Wally is disappointed the Boss has never praised him for a job well done.
Dilbert faced a choice at work: do something important or something useless that looked good.
Dilbert asks Carol where Asok is. She says it's not her job to keep track of the employees.
Alice wonders how Wally can be so relaxed when there is so much to do. Wally says he achieves his goals of not taking pride in his work.
Asok says Wally should not have eaten that burrito since he's not certified in ISO.
Dilbert asks if it's more important to follow the documented process or to meet the deadline.
A co-worker asks Wally for the new design specs. She doesn't expect Wally will actually provide them.
Before a meeting with a Marketing guy, Alice slams his head on the table.
strip.note: Two versions were published. One was for a meeting with Human Resources, the other for Marketing. Note that this alternative version may not have been official.

strip.synopsis: Catbert confronts Alice about her slamming the heads of Marketing people onto tables.
Alice, in an interview, slams the person's head on a table to find out the best place for him to work.
The Boss's plan for funding a new project involves playing budget chicken with a director.
The Boss interviews a job hopper who has had fifteen jobs in two months.
Dilbert tells a job hopper all jobs involve doing unpleasant things.
Dilbert is proud of his new powerpoint presentation.
The Boss says he didn't like Dilberts powerpoint presentation.
The Boss asks Dilbert to cut his presentation to the CEO down to five minutes.
Dilbert dumbs down his presentation to the CEO to help him make the right decision.
The Boss tells the story of the auto mechanic who takes a hammer to an engine to fix it.
Dogbert tells a stranger about his schadenfreude party.
Customers complain about price stickers leaving white crud on their product.
A consultant spouts obvious generalities about information.
A mildly retarded consultant mixes metaphors and spouts nonsense.
A consultant says he's getting paid the most but Dilbert is the smartest person in the room.
A new nemesis meets Dilbert and says his function is now handled formally.
The Boss says Dilbert doesn't need to provide specifications to the programmers as they already know what to do.
The office nemesis asks Dilbert to do cost-benefit analyses for every conceivable option.
The Boss says even though the engineers' jobs are underpaid and frustrating, every other company is the same.
Phil darns someone to heck for using a cell phone in a meeting.
Mordac tells Asok how to increase the storage limit for his e-mail.
Wally said he couldn't get any work done because pop-up messages kept appearing telling him to upgrade software on his computer.
Dilbert is determined to keep a positive attitude toward life no matter what happens.
The Boss introduces Phil O'Dendron, a potted plant who will sit in Dilbert's cubicle all day.
Wally says he'll quit and sell things on EBay.
Catbert confronts Wally about his side business of selling office supplies on EBay.
Wally's stack of disciplinary issues is very large and continues to grow.
Dilbert tells the Boss Wally has a laziness disability and can't be fired.
Not only can't Wally be fired, he is also employee of the month.
Alice is moved to a larger cubicle and she uses that to rule her co-workers with an iron fist.
Alice tells Asok not to tell the Boss anything while he's distracted.
Alice flaunts the fact she has a larger cubicle.
Wally says he couldn't do any work because Alice has a larger cubicle.
A man complains he's a technology left-behind.
The highlight of Wally's workday is his ham sandwich.
Alice uses mixed sports metaphors during a presentation.
An executive compensation review board meets and a clown suggests fifty million dollar salary for the CEO.
Even though Dilbert accomplished all his goals for the year, the Boss can't give much of a raise.
Dilbert is worried about buying a product that might have a new version next week.
The Boss hires a decorated army combat veteran.
Dilbert asks the army vet how is the transition to corporate life.
Dilbert and the war veteran swap hardship stories. Dilbert's was about running out of staples.
The Boss asks the war veteran to take a birthday card around for signatures.
Alice asks Dilbert what he will wear for Ted's wedding.
Dilbert tells Alice a new supplier will be found for the casing. Alice is worried it might not happen.
Dilbert is in charge of installing the system Lyin' John sold to their biggest customer.
Dilbert tells a customer he can't install the system Lyin' John sold them without losing money.
Dilbert reports the customer doesn't want to voluntarily pay more money to cover the bidding error.
Dogbert gives advice on how to get more money out of an underbid contract.
The Boss tells an interviewee he wants employees who are passionate.
The Boss's new strategy is to hire passionate people instead of smart ones.
Alice is always the one who has to fetch the extra chair for the meeting room.
The Boss sends Alice to a communication class.
Dogbert welcomes people to his communication seminar. He demonstrates how to pretend to listen while using a Blackberry.
Dogbert says there's no point in listening to other people. They either agree or say something stupid.
Dilbert provides the latest numbers from Yvonne, who had sextuplets, her house burned down and she had shoulder surgery.
Asok gives the Boss some hearsay about Ted's project.
The Boss tells Ted he heard Ted's project is floundering.
In Dogbert's school of management, he shows how to get employees to do the impossible.
Catbert gives asylum to Asok, the office snitch.
The Boss hires a lady because she is so attractive.
The Boss introduces Ellen, who is unqualified but totally hot.
Carol complains the Boss hired Ellen only because she's hot.
Dilbert wants to introduce himself to the new, hot employee.
Alice asks the Garbageman how to get rid of Ellen the new, hot employee.
Alice tells the Boss their new product is the worst on the market, according to the benchmarks. He asks her to re-test.
A new employee comes from a place with colourful folk sayings.
The Boss tries to get a straight answer out of the employee with lots of colourful sayings.
Asok can't decide about the employee with colourful sayings.
The Boss calls Dogbert's tech support. Dogbert advises slamming his hand in a drawer.
The Boss awards Ted a t-shirt for his work on the alpha project, then fires him. The t-shirt says "idiot."
The Boss asks Catbert how to assign blame for the failure of project alpha. Catbert suggests using the plunger of blame.
A reported for a business magazine interviews the Boss. He dispenses squirrel-related wisdom.
Dilbert asks why he received the plunger of blame. The Boss answers "because I can."
Dilbert asks the Garbageman how to get rid of the plunger of blame.
Dogbert says readers have asked for the return of Loud Howard. Dogbert says that makes no sense.
The Boss tells Loud Howard about an upcoming re-org and wants it kept a secret.
Loud Howard spreads the secret of the upcoming re-org.
Mindy demands Dilbert drops everything to make a change or else she'll spread a nasty rumour about him.
Dilbert complains attractive people are on his project. Attractive people are unproductive.
Dilbert tells the Boss he stayed up all night to work on Mindy's software because she threatened him.
Dilbert says his life consists of moving things from one place to another. He seeks a deeper meaning.
Wally says sadness is just another word for not enough coffee.
Dilbert reports he finished all his projects in one day, reconfigured the network, wrote white papers and applied for patents.
Because of the caffeine, Dilbert can predict the future.
Because of the coffee, Dilbert can levitate objects with his mind.
Catbert gets the new employee mainstreamed using their employee onboarding process.
Dilbert asks a doctor if he's drinking too much coffee.
The Boss asks Dilbert to cut down of coffee. Dilbert goes Darth Vader on him.
The Boss gives Alice a 3% raise because she did the work of three people.
Ratbert worries all his wisdom comes from bad analogies.
Ratbert wants to debate with people on the Internet, but may not be smart enough. So he just reads what smart people are saying.
Ratbert debates people on the Internet by always saying the same thing. He wins every argument.
The Boss goes to Dogbert's Motivational Speakers Bureau to hire a cheap speaker.
Carol complains Wally's popcorn makes it impossible to work. Wally says it's either his odour or the popcorn.
Another day of useless work and no accomplishment, but Dilbert says his personal life is meaningful.
Marketing asks for Wally's help on the new product. The product is worthless, too.
Wally sees the new product, which just occupies space and smells bad. They need a name for the product.
Ninety percent of the customers want to beat Wally to death with his stupid product.
Wally designs product collateral by comparing their product to even worse products.
Dogbert shows how to use your incompetence to achieve your career goals.
Dilbert discovers a dead co-worker in a cubicle.
Alice discovers a dead person in his cubicle. Dilbert had already seen him.
Wally stops by a dead co-workers cubicle to find out for sure if he's dead.
Carol reports to the Boss one of the employees is dead.
The Boss asks Dilbert to get data from a co-worker who doesn't answer his phone or e-mail.
Dilbert asks Dogbert how to get data from an unreachable guy. Dogbert says to just make up the data.
The Boss introduces his team to someone who will be making a proposal.
Topper says he strangled 900 insurgents with his bare hands.
Topper says he passed a kidney stone the size of a small horse.
Topper says he used too much tanning spray and Brand and Angelina adopted him.
Tina rewrites the project scope instead of just updating the project status.
Since the project scope was changed a team member asks to get off the project.
Dilbert says he doesn't have enough resources to do the project. The Boss says the project isn't important and neither is Dilbert.
Dilbert asks his date if she likes conversation. They can't agree on a good topic, though.
Alice meets a marketing guy who talks out of the ass on his head.
Dilbert asks a marketing guy for data on customer preferences. The marketing guy pulls it out of his ass on the top of his head.
strip.note: An early version showed the marketing guy ass on his head. The published version covered up the ass with underpants.

strip.synopsis: Dilbert combines lies from marketing with the Boss's assumptions and then factors in reality.
Dilbert meets a new, older, experienced employee.
Asok meets an older employee. The Boss asks Asok to explain what computers are.
The older employee says he didn't have ipods, cell phones, video games or computers when he was young.
The Boss introduces Six Sigma, the new methodology. Dilbert says it was a fad discredited years ago.
The Boss asks Asok to get the client a "little bit pregnant."
Dilbert helps a co-worker solve an engineering problem he's been working on for six months.
An accounting troll says they might need to restate the earnings. It turns out they're not allowed to make up numbers.
A news report says the company restated its earnings from a few frillion to a loss of a billion. Dilbert thinks it's humiliating.
Dilbert admits to a woman he worked at the company that restated its earnings.
The CEO wants to clear up questions about the restatement of earnings. Wally asks if he will return his 25 million dollar bonus.
The Boss wants Alice to use her vacation days by the end of the year but still wants the project done by then.
A contract employee says he can't enjoy time off because he only gets paid for the time he works.
Catbert says an absence counts as an occurrence no matter how long it is.
Carol has a candy dish on her desk but doesn't want Dilbert to take any candy.
Dogbert says machines are more important than some employees.
The only employee who knows how to program the legacy machines has quit. Dilbert is to step in.
A family of squirrels has taken over the legacy payroll database. They make demands.
Dogbert's tech support advises a man to hand over his personal identity and check into rehab.
Asok asks for the Boss's comments on a proposal before it is submitted.
Asok has telekinesis but is not allowed to use it in front of the ungifted.
Asok invents a room-temperature superconductor instead of finding a new vendor for toner cartridges.
Alice is interrupted by a cell phone during a presentation. She destroys the phone.
The Boss assigns Wally to the director of marketing because the Boss hates the director.
The director of marketing asks Wally if Wally can do an assignment right.
Dilbert asks the Boss why he never showed up for the budget meeting the Boss had requested.
Dilbert sent an overly brief e-mail which Tina interpreted as he hates her.
Dilbert tells Wally Tina is mad at him because of residual anger.
An insurance seller closes a deal and the client dies just after signing the contract.
An insurance seller closes a deal with the Boss just before the building catches fire.
A politician is having an affair with a squirrel, Dogbert tells Dilbert.
Wally teases that a politician had an affair with a squirrel. Dilbert responds another choked his secretary.
Wally tells Asok not to return dishes to the cafeteria. Someone else will do it instead.
Dilbert finds a way to save a million dollars for a cost of ten thousand. The Boss doesn't like it.
They don't pay enough to hire qualified employees so hire unqualified ones with good attitudes.
The Boss admits a new employee can't be trained, but doesn't want to fire him because there's now a hiring freeze.
A vampire gives a pep talk for the employees to donate blood. The vampire is not part of the Red Cross.
Catbert questions why the Boss allowed a vampire to run a blood drive.
The Boss asks Carol's advice on which diet to follow.
Dilbert must get approval from the change control board before talking with vendors to get their prices.
The Boss outlines the strategy in terms of food -- their meat and potatoes is their bread and butter.
The Boss announces he's on a diet and may not be as sharp as everyone expects him to be.
Wally eats a doughnut in front of the Boss to tease about his diet.
The Boss looks for a diet buddy to make it easier. Tina develops an eating disorder.
The Boss can't concentrate because of his diet so spouts worse gibberish than usual.
Dogbert, diet guru, gives the Boss some inspiration by threats.
strip.note: Scott published an alternative version where Dogbert calls the Boss an overweight walrus with diabetes.

strip.synopsis: Tina edits a letter before the Boss sends it. She starts by looking for words that aren't words and sees what's left.
The Boss makes Dilbert into a sales engineer and switches him to be paid on commission.
Dilbert, sales engineer, has to lie to cover up the sales rep's statements.
Dogbert shows Dilbert how to lie to be a good sales support engineer.
The sales rep made the sale, now Dilbert has to install the product. The rep promised some extra features as well.
The network product is a box of leaves and twigs. Dilbert has to integrate it into the network.
Dilbert hooks up a box of twigs and leaves into a customer's network by running a cable through it.
Carol schedules a pre-meeting for after the meeting as that's the only time where everyone was free.
Ratbert is so happy he sings.
Dilbert orders sugared doughnuts and always gets plain doughnuts. Ratbert always licks off the sugar.
Dogbert helps the Boss remember his password. It's "123."
Dogbert runs a password recovery service for morons. Ned uses his first name.
The Boss asks Carol to book a staff meeting. The topic uses a combination of buzzwords for strategy and objectives.
The Boss wants to close the gap between strategy and objectives.
All travel must be booked through the corporate web site. Alice complains about the discount Elbonian airlines.
An alien wants to work with engineers to transfer his great knowledge.
An alien wants to share his knowledge but the company doesn't allow it.
An alien tries to share his technology with Alice.
An alien is frustrated no one wants his advanced knowledge.
Dilbert doesn't want to attend a meeting right away because it will interrupt his lunch.
The Boss asks Asok to buy an award case then buy some awards to fill it.
A VP doesn't know who reports to him.
Dogbert comes up with a foolproof way to identify losers on the payroll.
Dogbert identifies a mutant who is the best fit for the job.
The new philosophy is called "a bias for action." Dilbert wants to know which program is being eliminated to make room.
Dilbert wants to make it to his cubicle without human contact.
The Boss asked for a button on the interface and then doesn't remember it.
Dilbert sees an opening for an engineer in research and development.
Dogbert kicks off the project by assigning blame for its eventual failure.
Dilbert asks for permission to apply for the job in R&D. The Boss applied there too.
The Boss gives a twenty-year service award.
Dilbert tells the Boss Marketing isn't cooperating.
The Boss asks Wally what are his goals for the coming year.
Asok said he set his year's goals higher than he can achieve.
The Boss worries Dilbert set a goal to decompose in his chair.
The Boss juggles budget money around while everyone else complains.
A co-worker invades Dilbert's personal space with his non-standard facial hair.
A co-worker gets lodged in Dilbert's ear. A doctor tells how to get him out.
Employee appreciation day costs $25 apiece.
Dilbert compares his project to fifteen drunken monkeys with a jigsaw puzzle.
The Boss volunteers management help for projects. No one wants it.
The Boss offers ideas about Alice's project. She does not want them.
The new company health plan is for everyone to use Google to diagnose their own problems.
Dogbert runs public relations for the company. He tells the media their products are deadly and are being recalled.
Dogbert, PR rep, convinces media to do a story on their products.
Dogbert tells the Boss to do something that has never been done, to get free publicity.
Dogbert convinces a reporter to publish his press release.
Dogbert says his PR campaign caused their stock price to be grossly over-inflated.
The Boss finds a dead horse in the hall and starts punching it.
The Boss puts Dilbert in charge of the project but does not give a budget or assign resources or allow Dilbert to create a project plan.
There's asbestos in the ceiling but Carol doesn't need to worry.
The employees are whiny about asbestos in the ceiling and the Boss in a hazmat suit.
Asok uses his telekinesis to take care of the asbestos problem.
A sales rep loses control when Dilbert asks about tax and shipping on the estimate.
A sales rep says Dilbert flipped out when she showed him the cost estimates.
Catbert confronts Alice about her punching a crazy co-worker.
Wally plans his excuses around Ted's vacation.
Wally passes around Ted's get well card.
Alice always solves problems caused by the Boss.
Asok asks Wally's advice on how to handle priorities.
Wally hasn't finished the detailed analysis because he's more of a big picture guy.
Wally enjoys disappointing people. He loves who he is.
Wally will speak about disappointing people for Dogbert's speakers bureau.
The Boss envisions a giant goals database for division goals, department goals and personal goals.
Dogbert books Wally to be the keynote speaker for a big company.
Wally advises his audience the source of all unhappiness is other people.
A financial adviser outlines his plan to invest Wally's money from demotivational speaking.
Wally didn't feel the need to work this week due to his outside income.
The Boss doesn't want to lose empty cubicles to other departments.
Wally takes his time writing a technical evaluation. The first draft says "blah, blah, blah."
Alice puts hazardous waste into the break room fridge to find out who's been eating her lunch.
Loneliness can only be cured by others listening to you, Dilbert says.
The Boss asks Asok to make a spreadsheet and track something. It doesn't matter what.
No e-mail on Fridays in order to boost productivity, the Boss announces.
Catbert tells Dilbert he as already reached full potential, so there's no reason to improve.
The career plan for Alice is to keep her around until an Elbonian can do her job for less, Catbert says.
Dilbert does things differently from the Boss, so he must be doing everything wrong.
Wally does some e-mail judo to keep from doing work.
Jeff the human ashtray comes close to Alice to share his aroma.
Jeff the human ashtray warns Dilbert about a hole in the ground, but it's just ash.
Jeff the human ashtray says he can be a good manager.
Jeff the human ashtray says there's more to being a manager than having an ashtray for a head.
strip.note: An early version of the strip shows Jeff sitting on the toilet and shows the toilet. The published version does a closeup of Jeff and does not show the toilet.

strip.synopsis: The Boss asks Dilbert to inventory the furniture. Dilbert wonders when the Boss will forget the Boss asked.
The Boss's department will be eliminated because the CEO doesn't understand what it does.
Dilbert has trouble talking with the Boss because he's always busy.
The Boss tells everyone the department will be eliminated because the CEO doesn't know what they do.
The Boss asks Asok to create some slides to describe what the department does and use a process called lying.
Wally recommends dishonesty when quantifying the benefits of the department.
Dogbert can quantify the unquantifiable.
Dogbert the quantifier recommends making absurd claims while hoping no one asks questions.
Dogbert the quantifier says an artist is worth $85.
If Dilbert invented something to give him unlimited power, Dogbert would kill him and take it.
Catbert hired two for Dilbert's project -- a mumbler and hard of hearing.
Tina says Dilbert's success diminishes her.
Alice wants comments by e-mail because Ted might change his story later.
Ted denies seeing the design but Alice shows him his comments.
Tina wants to know why engineers are paid more than technical writers.
Tina enjoys pointing out Dilbert's mistakes.
The company lawyer says it's hard to find a product name. The good ones are taken and so are the bad ones.
Dilbert spends his time planning and scheduling work, and explaining why he never has time to do actual work.
Wally sells his remaining soul to Catbert for a doughnut.
Catbert detects a glimmer of hope in Dilbert.
Catbert detects a reincarnated soul in Asok and fixes it so next time the soul can't escape his dead body.
The new product can download pictures, smells, tastes and celebrity tickling patterns.
The new product is so good people starve to death while using it, Dilbert tells his date.
Half the department will be outsourced, but the Boss can't tell anyone.
It has been a long meeting and Alice is anxious to wrap it up so prevents other issues from being raised.
Alice has a bad case of chair buttocks but can still lead a normal life.
strip.note: An early version of the strip shows Alice on her hands and knees on the doctor's table. There's also a closeup cropped image showing the doctor's face up Alice's butt. The published version shows Alice leaning over a table and the Doctor farther away.

strip.synopsis: A doctor shows Alice normal buttocks and compares to her box-shaped ones.
The Boss is starting a blog about the business and asks Tina to write it.
Tina's blog post for the Boss isn't witty enough, he says.
The CEO tells the Boss the Boss's blog has become an embarrassment to the company.
The Boss wants to show off a concept product, similar to concept cars from automotive companies.
Dogbert is getting Elbonians to make running shoes in Dilbert's basement.
An Elbonian asks Dilbert to help him escape from Dogbert's running-shoe factory in the basement.
A cartoonist in a cubicle may embarrass the company so the Boss must assign absurd work until he quits.
A cartoonist looks around the office for inspiration.
The Boss asks the cartoonist to stop mocking the management of the company in the newspapers.
The cartoonist says his side job is doing well so he hands in his resignation to the Boss.
A new guy asks Dilbert how long before the dark cloud of hopelessness and despair begins to go away.
Dilbert ignores e-mail from people who don't include his original message in their reply.
A co-worker complains Dilbert never answers her e-mail. He says her e-mails are hard to read.
Wally goes to meetings and never gets any action items by using a certain facial expression to ward them off.
After his presentation, Dilbert asks if there are any questions designed to increase his workload for their entertainment.
Dogbert's tech support advises to turn off everything including lights, water heater, microwave and refrigerator.
Dogbert's tech support selects a product from the caller's computer to blame for all the problems.
Disgruntled Doug is to work on the company's pricing model, and the Boss puts him in a cardboard box instead of a cubicle.
A co-worker asks to move to a window cubicle after 25 years without one.
Dilbert is happy no one can take his name until his credit card company calls and says someone stole his identity.
Dogbert advises the Boss to get a dashboard application to show metrics so he can ignore it when making policy decisions.
The Boss is worried the metrics on his dashboard aren't good so needs to falsify them.
The Boss awards Carol some morale dollars she can use to redeem for gifts and services she doesn't want or need.
The Boss asks Ted to work late every night until they catch up. And work every weekend.
Every project Dilbert worked on got cancelled after the reorganisation. It's like he didn't exist.
Dilbert asks a co-worker to sign off on a plan in writing so he can't raise any objections later.
Other department heads won't sign off on the business plan so they'll look good in comparison.
At a productive management retreat, they golfed hard until they came up with a new vision for the company.
Catbert asks Asok to have more of a winner's mentality.
Ted is so busy his head explodes.
strip.note: This strip is almost identical to one published on 2008-09-18.

strip.synopsis: Dilbert is asked to help with a technical analysis but wants his lawn mowed in return.
Alice is employee of the month but doesn't want any of the rewards.
Dogbert the lawyer threatens a web page company for stealing people's cursors.
Ratbert teases Dilbert he will wear clothes he doesn't want to wear and spend the day where he doesn't want to be.
Ratbert brags he will be eating Dilbert's computer cables.
Asok gets a text message from the Boss. "KEEP UP WRK."
Rebels threaten to attack the Elbonian factory unless they get a million dollars. Dilbert negotiates.
Dilbert negotiates with the Elbonian rebels so they won't attack the factory.
The Boss brings Dilbert along to the CEO meeting in case of technical questions. The Boss says to be completely honest.
Dilbert reaches an agreement with the Elbonian rebels. The rebels get stock instead of a ransom.
The company is funding terrorists. Very indirectly and not the bad kind of terrorists.
The new dress code is a thin film of oil so they can fit twenty people in a cubicle.
The company has given up trying to win one of the "best places to work" awards.
A co-worker turns 50 and says he never felt better.
Asok can't get the necessary software to do his job so must share a computer with someone else who has it.
Is Dilbert's plan consistent with the corporate strategy? He doesn't know as he's never seen the strategy.
Wally mapped and gapped the requirements to consolidate everything into a program of work.
The CEO makes meetings go faster by saying opinions are treason.
The CEO wants everyone to be passionate for their jobs. His is working everyone like a rented mule.
The Boss wrote his password on his forehead and wants Dilbert to read it.
The Boss wants a productivity simulation of half the workforce is lost due to a pandemic.
Everyone must charge to the appropriate project code, or lie if their project is unfunded.
Dilbert is annoyed by whistling so summons Alice to handle the situation.
To save the environment Dogbert gives bad career advice to get a person fired and no longer commutes.
Dogbert advises to stop eating, breathing, driving, defecating and procreating. And start decomposing.
Dogbert recommends slamming SUVs into hybrids to get them off the road altogether.
Dogbert starts collecting methane from Wally, enough to power a small building.
Asok can't get Alice's attention because he's not important.
Asok's central nervous system starts to atrophy.
Dilbert wants to hit himself with a hammer rather than running a paper by an attorney.
A new hire has too many personal problems.
Nancy is in love with a medical school cadaver.
Nancy eats too much licorice and diet soda and has joined Al Qaeda.
Dogbert, career counsellor, advises a client to do something he loves.
Dogbert, career counsellor, says a client has no marketable talent and is unemployable.
A man with a degree in flower arranging wants to be a billionaire.
Wally didn't get the benchmark tests done because of global warming.
It's Catbert's fault the company is losing market share.
Catbert decides to segment the compensation of different classes of employees.
Dilbert wants to invite friends over for a barbecue but needs to make some friends first.
Carol arranges the executive golf tournament. She put cigar smokers in the Boss's foursome. Lunch is baked beans and sauerkraut.
The Boss is off to the executive golf tournament. He realises the contrast between his job and Carol's.
Asok caddies for the Boss in a golf tournament. Asok confuses a sand wedge and a sandwich.
Dogbert convinces a management consultant firm to hire him as a management consultant.
Dilbert attends an all-hands meeting.
Ted's job is outsourced and he gets a job with the outsourcer.
No one at Dilbert's meeting has any knowledge or the authority to make decisions.
Carol sets up a dinner for key employees, who are everyone except her.
Having internal phone lists are against policy bu the Boss doesn't know why.
No drinking coffee at work is the new policy. Policies are for evil purposes.
Wally applies for a job he's unqualified for to use it to negotiate for a raise.
The Boss will be managing the Elbonian branch office, but back in his own country.
The Boss says Elbonians won't work unless they're watched constantly.
The Boss asks for feedback on the idea of hiring a project coordinator. Everyone thinks it's a bad idea.
New employees learn they'll have no time for exercise. They'll work long hours and consume trans fats.
Dilbert is promoted from senior engineer to lead engineer. The pay is the same.
Dilbert is promoted to lead engineer and so is Wally. They're both disappointed.
Alice and Dilbert get Asok to raise the issue that the project uses old technology instead of new.
Tina complains Wally's snacks are too loud.
Tina complains to Catbert Wally eats loud snacks in his cubicle.
Alice visits a psychologist about her urge to punch people who deserve it.
Wally receives many e-mails from the Boss, all marked highest priority. So he spent the entire week working on the first one.
The Boss hires Dogbert's moving company to relocate Ted. The movers are cheap.
The automated test software has been cut from the budget so the Boss asks Dilbert to write it.
Dilbert tries to get the system price from a vendor but all she talks about is delivery time.
Dilbert can't get an automated testing system by the Boss's deadline so Dilbert needs to work smarter with a bias for action.
There are two kinds of management problems -- those than can be solved by yelling and the kind that can be solved by buying software.
The Boss buys software to yell at Wally.
Wally wears noise cancellation headphones to a meeting. The Boss doesn't like it.
The Boss wants open-source software for everything. It's free.
Wally says there's two options, one that costs too much, the other won't work.
Dilbert asks a vendor when the next model comes out. If it's two months, Dilbert will wait until then.
Tina leaves a note on Dilbert's monitor, also leaves a voicemail and sends an e-mail.
The Boss decides to manage by spreadsheet and track things until problems fix themselves.
Asok is doing a terrible job according to the Boss's spreadsheet. Asok thinks the spreadsheet must be poorly conceived.
The Boss asks Carol to cancel all his meetings. He'll be managing by spreadsheet and e-mail.
Dogbert wears tall pants and an old-fashioned hairpiece because he's running for president.
Dogbert makes campaign promises -- anti-terrorism, tax policies, pollution, health.
Dilbert is to prepare a proposal for something they don't have the right products or expertise.
Dogbert says in his fist hundred days as president, he'll carve his initials in all the furniture.
Dogbert asks Ratbert to be his vice-presidential running mate, and be very unpopular.
The Boss asks for a meeting to prepare for a meeting to decide how to decide.
The CEO doesn't understand the Boss so sends him away. The Boss blames it on Dilbert.
The Boss hires a coffee-swilling beaver to help Carol.
strip.note: An enlargement of the final panel was published on Scott's blog.

strip.synopsis: The coffee swilling beaver says he has no impulse control.
strip.note: An enlargement of the final panel was published on Scott's blog.

strip.synopsis: The Boss calls a meeting to discuss changes to the pension plan. Everyone already saw the e-mail.
The Boss tells each person they are the highest paid engineer but not to tell anyone.
A woman at a party had a facelift that lets her see over the tops of cubicles.
Stockholders complain the CEO earned $72 million while the stock price dropped nine percent.
Dilbert says his boyhood dream of working in a fabric-covered box came true.
Dilbert sorts the product features into priorities -- essential, critical and must-have.
The CEO sells some company goodwill.
Dilbert can't get a raise because he asked too many questions.
Dogbert redesigns the headquarters after purchasing the company's goodwill.
Dogbert asks for customers to be injured after buying company goodwill.
Catbert installs sensors to detect happy thoughts when people should be working.
Wally's brain monitor proves he never thinks about work.
The Boss made a typo so has to let Ted go.
The Boss made a typo in the budget so Dilbert can't get hardware or software for the lab.
Dilbert is to mentor the new intern -- the CEO's son.
The Boss hires three hundred people to complete a project that will take three hundred man days.
Asok completed his work and asks for more. The Boss asks him to create a document and route it around for approval.
An Elbonian with a skunk asks for directions to the microwave.
Carl is fired because he's totally incompetent at everything.
Carl is to train Dilbert on how to do his job after being fired for gross incompetence.
Dilbert's new circuit design is worse than the old one, the Boss hears.
Asok didn't finish his tasks for the meeting so Wally gives him a powerful anti-meeting spell.
Dogbert gets campaign support from the military industrial complex.
The Boss asks Alice to see him at the end of the day but she's worried when he doesn't say why.
People complain about how Wally opens a security door -- by putting his card in his front pocket and thrusting it at the sensor.
The Boss says they can't compete on price, quality, features or service.
The new VP of marketing promises to improve revenues by ten billion percent.
Dogbert spraypaints the roadkill by using dishonesty.
strip.note: On his blog, Scott Adams showed a panel with different dialog.

strip.synopsis: A negotiator isn't authorised to make any changes to the contract, so wears people down.
Dogbert translates technical terms into marketing language.
The head of public relations has to explain Dogbert's marketing claims.
A co-worker brags to Alice about getting a window cubicle.
Dilbert tells his date he saw a documentary about bugs.
Wally says he needs constant supervision so didn't get the cost estimates.
Carol hasn't updated the org chart because she keeps waiting for it to become important.
The product design is worse than the old design, but the designer didn't know it was supposed to be better.
Dogbert makes a campaign promise to never make decisions based on opinion polls.
Dogbert promises a potential political donor to run the bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms.
Dilbert despairs none of his efforts will mean anything.
The Boss does some generic management and inquires about the talk to whats-his-name about the thing.
Wally is late because he'll work unverifiable hours after the Boss leaves.
Catbert questions Wally about his loyalty to the company. He uses phrasing to confuse the issue.
Dilbert does carpet fishing in his cubicle. He uses a grid on the carpet and a randomising program on his computer.
The Boss asks why it took Dilbert six months to complete a simple task. Dilbert blames it on the Boss's management style.
The Boss hires a sadist to thin the herd.
The sadist says Wally is worthless and overpaid. Wally doesn't care.
The Boss wants people to use vacation by year end then criticises Asok for taking time off.
Asok works extra hard to finish his work before his vacation. Dilbert goes home early.
Dilbert criticises a co-worker's powerpoint and calls it useless and has wino's spittle.
The mandatory meeting on employee health and well-being starts at 6AM so as not to interfere with work.
Dilbert is honest on his timesheet and charges less of his time to projects than all the other engineers.
Dilbert's date says he treats all their conversations like a contest where he has too be the one who is right.
Wally says the new hire is a weasel and liar. The Boss says that's just so the Boss won't believe him when the new hire complains about Wally.
The Boss hires an unqualified crony to run the quality control group. He values loyalty over competence.
Dilbert complains the Boss's unqualified crony is causing rebellion among the staff. The Boss doesn't believe him.
Alice targets Keith for elimination. She'll start rumours to convince everyone he is dishonest and incompetent.
Asok found a clever way to write his code in an hour. The Boss now expects him to finish all his projects in an hour.
Keith complains to Catbert Alice is spreading false rumours about him. Catbert says the company doesn't worry about the difference between rumours and facts.
Dilbert can't get a raise but the Boss lets him have two flat screen monitors.
Tina complains Dilbert has two computer monitors but she only gets one. The Boss says yhat's because men are better negotiators.
The Boss asks Dilbert to make changes to a document and run it by him again. Dilbert thinks he's entered an infinite loop.
Wally says he increased his productivity by improving his morale. He watched Youtube videos all day.
Dogbert the security consultant asks everyone to look out for suspicious behaviour. If they see someone do what they wouldn't do, they are to beat the person to death with a trash can.
Wally says he helped Alice finish her project on time. He did this by not insisting she get data for his project.
Dogbert the security consultant says anyone without a badge should be locked in a janitor's closet until he starves.
Dilbert says he can't do his work because the Internet is too fascinating.
Dilbert tells a psychologist he's addicted to the Internet. Direct human interaction is too shallow and predictable.
Catbert announces all sick days need to be scheduled in advance. Alice wonders how that's supposed to work.
Dilbert wonders why decisions in the workplace seem to have been made by drunken lemurs. The garbageman responds decisions are made by people who have time, not people who have talent.
A co-worker wants to give Dilbert some advice. Dilbert wants to respond by rolling his eyes, sighing loudly and dismissing the advice.
Ratbert says he's happy his brain is empty. Stress is just another word for knowledge.
A co-worker wonders why Dilbert didn't use any of his suggestions. Dilbert says it's because his brain is the size of a marble.
Dogbert says all the scientists think the company's products harm the environment so recommends paying weasels to cast doubt on the data.
Dogbert goes to Rent-a-Weasel to hire unsuccessful scientists and lazy journalists to take the opposing view.
Ratbert says he's always wrong about everything. Dogbert advises him to shop because the customer is always right.
Ratbert tries to buy snow tires for a refrigerator in a lingerie shop.
The Boss asks Dilbert to bring him solutions instead of problems.
Wally prevents Asok from talking directly with the VP of Sales. He must use the chain of command instead.
A sales rep says the quoted price includes everything. Dilbert asks about taxes, shipping, cables, upgrades, maintenance and insurance.
Alice suggests Dilbert check with Ted to see if he knows about that sort of thing.
The Boss says their new strategy has never worked for anyone before, so will give them the element of surprise.
Dilbert says he needs a bar code scanner to finished his lab tests. The Boss gives him many hurdles to clear before getting one.
The Boss asks when Dilbert can provide his status report for the project.
A new co-worker said everything was done better at his old company.
Tina asks Wally for comments on her article. Wally puts her off with excuses.
Asok must fill in at tech support for a few days. His job will be to slow the customer down.
The Boss doesn't understand anything Dilbert does, so assumes it's all useless.
Asok tries to develop a good attitude about his work, even busywork.
The Boss says they program their website using a fast guy in tights an a movie about coffee. Dilbert says it's flash and javascript.
Mordac believes security is more important than usability and in a perfect world, no one could use anything.
Mordac shows Dilbert the newest biometric scanner, a head clamp to make him scream.
Dilbert talks to students on career day. Engineers explain things to idiots. Then idiots misinterpret things engineers say.
Dogbert offers two alternatives. Lies for $400 per hour or the truth for $200.
Dilbert wants to order pens. Carol says it's impossible because it takes a pen to fill in the form to order pens.
A co-worker says the backup server is overkill. Dilbert says the document says the opposite.
The company will become more family-friendly. And they'll be openly hostile to single people.
Carol wants to take advantage of the family friendly policy by looking after her kids.
Dilbert asks a job candidate why they should hire a person who has lots of spelling errors on his resume.
The Boss asks Dilbert to do something but doesn't have time to explain what it is properly.
The Boss says they'll try agile programming. No more planning or documentation. Just write code and complain.
The Boss says Tina's pay will be based on the number of pages she writes. So she says she'll produce a high volume of low quality pages.
Tina produces lots of writing. It was easier after she realised accuracy and clarity are optional.
Wally grows a goatee. He's using his powers of extreme uncoolness to make others' goatees go away.
Dogbert's tech support says he's never seen the caller's problem before, so he must be a liar or crazy.
The Boss says they're not to say they don't have enough resources. Instead, say their resources are dedicated to other, higher priorities.
Tina asks for a minute of Dilbert's time. He say no because it always takes longer than she says.
The next project is a private shuttle to the moon. If there are any mistakes, innocent tourists will die.
Dilbert complains to Dogbert he has to design a private moon shuttle in three months. Dogbert says he send over a scapegoat.
The Boss asks Asok to test pilot their new moon shuttle prototype. Asok suggests a monkey instead.
Asok gets into the moon shuttle prototype. His co-pilot is the grim reaper.
The Boss reports Asok died during the test of their new moon shuttle prototype.
Dilbert clones Asok from his DNA. The DNA gets mixed up with some candy.
The Boss asks Dilbert for an estimate. Dilbert says he hasn't had time to gather requirements. The Boss says he won't hold him to the estimate.
Dilbert tells Asok he died in space and was cloned from some DNA. Now Asok has to reincarnate into his clone.
Asok compares stories with Carol. Asok died and reincarnated into his own clone, then did some shape shifting.
Carol asks Wally to not drink so much coffee. Then she won't have to order so much.
Mordac made some network changes and is on vacation for three weeks, out of touch.
Wally complained he couldn't work as everything he had to do needed something else done first. Like a mobius strip.
A co-worker asks Wally why he's at her meeting. He says he's creating the illusion of work.
The Boss can't give Dilbert the maximum raise as he didn't exceed expectations. Dilbert said the expectations were set too high.
The Boss interviews a dead horse and asks if he can take a beating.
The Boss hired a dead horse and introduces him to the group. He says the horse can do good work if beaten enough.
The Boss can't tell Dilbert about the politics of his project, nor tell him about the new strategic direction or the upcoming reorg.
The Boss asks Alice to move to a cubicle closer to the rest of the department. Alice asks why.
Wally asks to skip the staff meeting because it will waste an hour of his life.
The Boss asks Dilbert what he's done to enhance their strategy into the next adjacency. Dilbert doesn't know what that means.
The Boss is off to the management retreat. He won't be reachable because he'll be too busy golfing, swimming and drinking. Carol is to count sheets of paper while he's gone.
Dilbert finished the useful part of his presentation and asks for questions from unqualified people.
The Boss moves Bruce to a different job because he's totally incompetent at his old job.
Wally did not finish his tasks because he thought other people wouldn't finish their tasks either.
Dilbert complains his new cubicle is too small. Catbert says he was spoiled before.
Alice submits her resignation. The Boss asks her to stay for a 20% raise. She accepts.
Ratbert wants to know what kind of party they're having for New Year's Eve. Dilbert says there's no sense in a party.
Alice is interviewed for a management job. She says she wants it because of money, prestige, abusing subordinates and she speaks fluent managerese.
Wally is upset because people stop working on the day before a holiday. He does it all year round.
Dilbert is happy he had a great day at work. No one interrupted and he got s lot done.
Dilbert tells Tina he came into work on New Year's day because he forgot it was a holiday.
Wally didn't have time to finish the traffic estimates because he spent all week shopping on the company's online supply ordering site.
Wally doesn't want to attend a meeting on Friday morning because it's bagel Friday.
Asok is creeped out because he heard the Boss hired a mole.
Topper says he hasn't slept in a month, died went to heaven, returned as a zombie and more.
Ratbert, employee mole, reports what the people think of the Boss -- a worthless, self-important gas bag.
Ratbert announces he is the secret mole who will report all missteps to the Boss.
Asok is worried none of his projects relate to the company's priorities.
Tina is to make it look like the budget aligns to the company's priorities.
The Boss complains Dilbert's design will never work in the real world.
Asok asks Catbert what he can do to get a raise.
Dilbert is to help Ted on his project. Dilbert wonders what's in it for him.
The Boss takes Wally out of the loop because it's too hard to keep everyone informed.
Wally's new cubicle is a giant mushroom because he's out of the loop.
Asok wants to present his project to the board of directors.
Asok wonders who will present his project to the board of directors.
The CEO presents Asok's slides to the board of directors even though he doesn't understand them.
Asok learns the CEO didn't understand the slides Asok made.
Dilbert tells Catbert he has a bad attitude because his project is failing and the Boss is no help.
Wally says he is an incubator of innovations.
Ratbert is assigned to configure the new software.
Ratbert tells Alice not to interfere while he configures the software.
Alice tells the Boss the new software is a disaster.
Wally says his new chair can be configured so many ways, it's probably configured wrong.
An Elbonian wants to be hired and will demean himself to the Boss.
Alice basks in the time between plans are made and someone thwarts them.
Alice gives the Boss an hour to make a difficult decision.
Dilbert pre-rejects a co-worker's idea.
Dogbert, financial planner, says a person could live to be 200 but most of the time will be in squalor.
Dogbert, financial planner, insults a client by saying investing is too complicated.
Dilbert says his hobby is to read obscure articles on the Internet.
The Boss tells Alice he can't give a large raise because his superiors will reduce it.
Dilbert says his work is hopeless.
Accounting rejects Dilbert's travel expenses.
Alice shows the Boss to her daughter and calls him inefficient.
A girl in the office says her career choices are prison guard or monkey trainer.
Dilbert wants to ask a question to the Boss but knows he'll be interrupted.
Dilbert asks how can the Boss make a 5 year plan when 5 minutes is too much.
The competitors made the 5 year plan moot.
Dogbert analyses each employee for their career potential.
A security person recommends putting sensitive material into envelopes marked top secret.
The Boss wants to virtualise servers to save electricity.
The Boss hires Dogbert to help with the server virtualisation. Dogbert says he expects the employees to act as obstacles.
Dogbert outlines his plan for server virtualisation -- monkeys will unplug servers then hurl software at whatever is left.
Dogbert presents his bill for server virtualisation. It's a big bill but there are no trouble tickets.
Wally expects a talented employee to leave the company so wants to get whatever is left behind.
The Boss tries the tough love style of management.
Asok is warned not to get friendly with the new employee as his armpits are 66 inches high.
Asok seeks electric cubicle walls to prevent a co-worker from leaning on the walls.
The Boss asks Wally about a comic strip he posted that compares managers to drunken lemurs.
Catbert fires Wally for posting a comic strip that compares managers to drunken lemurs.
Wally says he's not bitter for being fired for posting a comic strip on the wall.
Dogbert interviews the Boss for firing an employee for posting a comic strip on the wall.
Dogbert gives advice to Dilbert when he goes to a singles mixer.
Wally's lawyer Bob slaps the Boss with a suit for firing him.
Bob the lawyer reports to Wally the Boss agreed to rehire him.
Each department that signs off on a proposal adds a brick to the wall of approval.
An IT rep does not like the fact the engineers are building an effigy of him out of coffee supplies.
Catbert writes requirements for a job opening, including an IQ of 300, two centuries of Unix experience and several Nobel prizes.
Catbert interviews a job applicant who meets all the impossible requirements he set out.
Dilbert offers his opinion of a co-worker's idea -- dumber than snake mittens.
The company is like a family where the culture is based on trust and respect, but employees must agree to drug tests and searches.
Wally asks Catbert for a new title containing the word "architect."
Dilbert's date says a piano fell on her brother. Dilbert laughs.
Carol sees the department payroll report. The Boss doesn't want anyone else to see it.
Ratbert advises Dilbert to renounce his Internet addiction and live for the moment.
The Boss introduces a new team leader named Jesus, pronounced Hay-soos.
Dilbert says the online budget approval system doesn't work.
Jesus the new employee gets rid of Wally's baldness.
Jesus the new employee recruits Asok for the new project.
Wally tells the CEO Jesus the new employee wants to be CEO.
Wally taunts Jesus, the new employee, after being fired.
Jesus returns to work as a consultant after being fired.
Tina wonders why Dilbert asked a question she answered last week.
Measure twice and cut once, the Boss says. Dilbert says that doesn't apply to most situations.
Dilbert opens the floor to soul-crushing negativity after presenting his plan.
Dilbert asks the Garbageman for advice on how to regain his soul.
Dilbert tells his date how he had his soul crushed by co-workers.
Dilbert tries to help other people to regain his lost soul.
Dilbert asks Catbert if there is a company program to regain his lost soul.
Tina offers to help Dilbert regrow his head Catbert had slapped off.
Dilbert asks his doctor for a note saying he was sick.
Dilbert wants to leave a document for Carol in a place that won't get lost in the desk clutter.
Dogbert the archaeologist tries to find a budget report in Carol's cluttered desk.
Dilbert is late to a meeting, but says it's not his fault.
Dilbert tells his date his cable wasn't working last night so didn't have TV or Internet.
Dilbert lets the Boss say what the next step is so he can maintain the illusion of value.
The Boss asks Catbert if he is as predictable as Dilbert says.
Dilbert says the security audit locked all the developers out of the system. The Boss is no help.
There will be no raises because all the money was put toward a new coffee maker.
Wally meets the new coffee maker. It's aggressive.
Alice interviews a job candidate. He left his previous job because he punched his boss.
Dilbert asks Alice if she needs any help on her project.
Mordac asks how the system distinguishes between authorised and illegal access.
Alice represents the Boss in a meeting, then acts stupid.
Wally complains he couldn't work because the Boss didn't answer the 25 questions he asked.
The Boss asks Wally if he has the capital cost estimates that were requested last week.
The Boss tells Ted he's fired, then says not really but now a 2% raise isn't so bad.
A young person tells Dilbert he will rule the planet based on his knowledge of MySpace, Youtube and e-mail.
The Boss asks Dilbert if he made the requested changes.
Wally advises Asok to not finish projects ahead of the deadline.
The Boss asks a temp to find power cables in the flooded parking lot.
Alice and a co-worker discuss the best way to work together -- an exchange of ideas, or Alice mocking and abusing him.
Loud Howard is moved to a private office because he insists on using a speakerphone in his cubicle.
The Boss schedules a daily five-minute meeting to solve problems and share successes.
At a team huddle, no one has a successes to share.
Alice is jealous of Dilbert having two flat-screen monitors in his cubicle.
The Boss wants the engineers to have the same emotional investment in the company as they have with their families.
Marketing is proud sales have increased by 100%.
Dilbert complains to the Boss no one wants to be left out of the decision making but no one wants to make a decision.
Asok uses his telekinesis to neutralise the power of the stink eye.
Asok get summoned to the Indian Institute of Technology to explain his use of telekinesis.
Asok is punished for his use of telekinesis.
The Boss announces strategic alternatives, which means the company is for sale.
The Boss introduces the new strategic partner, an alien who eats Ted.
Dilbert is assigned to handle due diligence for the alliance with the Galactic Protein Corporation.
The Boss takes credit for an idea the engineers came up with. The CEO is undecided as to whether it's a good idea.
Dilbert recommends against a merger with the alien corporation.
Dilbert asks for help from Dogbert's Deus Ex Machina Services for getting out of the merger.
Dogbert recommends a poison pill to get out of the unfriendly takeover.
Dogbert searches for a new CEO to replace the one who died during the hostile takeover.
The Boss announces researchers have found a way to turn fresh water into fuel.
Dilbert meets his new project team member who has the stink of failure.
Dilbert leads a project but can't check the others' work even though they do bad work.
Dilbert asks a co-worker for help but he now carries the scent of failure.
The Garbageman tells how to get rid of the scent of failure.
Dilbert says all the databases are wrong, so can't size the market.
Dilbert doesn't have accurate numbers so he makes them up.
The company invests a billion dollars based on Dilbert's made up numbers.
The quality control budget is cut to allow for a larger sales force.
A co-worker complains she can't open the attachment Wally sent. Wally offers lots of excuses.
Asok adds photocopying to his duties.
Asok tries to delegate the photocopying assignment to Carol.
The Boss asks Asok where are his photocopies.
Dilbert, Alice and Asok were all assigned the same task a month ago.
Dilbert asks for the approved vendor list. Alice and Asok already asked for it.
Dilbert tells a stranger he is one of three people assigned to do a task because they're all unreliable.
The Boss says Alice's intolerance for others is the reason he can't give her the maximum raise.
Dilbert worked all night to finish the assignment on time. The Boss says to toss it on the pile.
A co-worker wants to date Dilbert for a month, long enough to resolve some tech issues at home.
Dilbert's girlfriend wants him to wear a toolbelt when he come over tonight.
After Dilbert fixed her satellite connection, Dilbert's date asks him to leave.
Dilbert tells Dogbert he is dating a girl because she wants free tech support.
Dilbert needs a new computer but there's no budget for one.
Dilbert goes to Human Resources for a psychological evaluation. Catbert asks how many bodies are hidden in his crawl space.
Dilbert asks to use the Boss's laptop until there's budget to get him a new computer.
Dilbert says he didn't work on the request this week because his computer is broken.
Dilbert tries to smuggle in his home laptop into work to replace his broken computer.
Catbert asks a job applicant to role play like an unqualified loser.
Catbert asks a job applicant to role play like a turtle being attacked by a hawk.
Wally is busy reading the In Memoriam section of the company newsletter.
Dilbert won't get a raise this year because his project is late even though it's not his fault.
Wally blames his lack of productivity on dead people and those who never existed.
Wally is enrolled in a class to cure hopelessness, along with a glass hammer and a bag of nothing.
Wally learns to carry two coffee cups in his class to be less useless.
Wally is not as useless has he used to be, now he is more helpless.
Dilbert summarises a technical report on a complicated slide.
Dilbert's recommendation to cancel all design projects was accepted by the executive steering committee.
Dogbert produces a reality show about Dilbert's life.
The Boss assumes Asok didn't do any work because he never raised any issues.
The company decides to write off bad debt. The CEO blames it on bad regulatory oversight.
Dogbert gives advice to the CEO on media relations. Don't compare to circling the drain.
Dogbert and the CEO do a mock interview to see how he responds under pressure.
The Boss demands an interest-free loan from a tiny vendor.
A tiny company complains they can't survive if their invoices are paid late.
The Boss tells Ted a funny story about trying to print a long document.
Catbert decides to gossipsize Ted by telling vicious lies until Ted decides to quit.
Carol heard Ted thinks a monkey could do her job.
Ted asks for Dogbert's help to squash rumours about himself.
Dogbert tries to control rumours about Ted by telling new ones.
Catbert announces surveillance cameras to monitor the engineers' work.
The engineers, besides having their actions monitored, now get their thoughts monitored as well.
Wally says he won't retire, just keep his job and stop caring about his work.
The Boss is off for two weeks of vacation. The engineers celebrate.
Dilbert is in charge while the Boss is on vacation. He asks Carol to format a report.
Dilbert expects everyone to be professional and productive while he's filling in for the vacationing Boss.
Carol tells the Boss everything is fine while he's on vacation.
Dilbert needs to attend a meeting while the Boss is on vacation. He'll be bullied into making bad decisions.
Dilbert is asked to take a budget cut while he's filling in for the Boss.
The company will spend the bonus money on an inspirational movie about being happy about no money.
Dilbert tests his particle accelerator to look for the antiworld.
Dilbert's double from the antiworld can't leave the vacuum.
Dilbert brings the antimatter Dilbert to work.
Anti-Dilbert tells Wally about his double -- a billionaire, entrepreneur and adventurer.
Alice destroys Anti-Dilbert's matterscreen and causes him to be destroyed.
Alice tells Dilbert she destroyed his antimatter duplicate.
Dilbert invites a female co-worker for a drink after work.
Alice hasn't made any code changes because the specs are vague.
Dogbert's seminar on time management and evolution -- skip unimportant tasks.
Don't put time into tasks that have no benefit, Dogbert the time management expert says.
Dogbert, the time management expert, says it doesn't matter what this employee does with his time.
Dilbert's salary is already above the midpoint for his pay range.
Dilbert wants to take classes in business so he can get promoted to management.
Wally demonstrates to Asok he doesn't have to keep up with changes in technology.
After being hit with a rock, Dilbert wakes up more qualified to be a natural leader.
The Boss realises Dilbert is the one the prophesies talk about -- the natural.
Catbert tests Dilbert to make sure his moral compass is broken.
Dilbert throws his coffee on a co-worker because he's being groomed for upper management.
Dilbert is promoted to vice president of making employees feel miserable and helpless.
Dilbert makes Asok feel miserable and helpless by showing him a chart of the sort of women who are attracted to men at different salary ranges.
Dilbert explains why he didn't accomplish any objectives this quarter -- they are impossible or illegal.
Dilbert's moral compass has healed. He wants to keep his job in upper management.
Dilbert wants to bring charges against the CEO for flinging him out a window.
Dilbert's date wants him to give her a back rub, even though he has two injured hands.
Dilbert is injured and wants sympathy from Dogbert.
Dilbert seeks a support group of people who were thrown out a window by a CEO.
Bob the lawyer serves legal papers to Dilbert's CEO.
The Boss says Asok will have to act independently on his project and imagine what the Boss would say.
Dilbert asks Dogbert to represent him in his lawsuit against his CEO.
Dogbert selects dumb people for the jury.
Dogbert asks the first question to the CEO in the trial. Where was he when Dilbert was pushed out a window?
The jury finds in favour of Dilbert in his suit against the CEO.
Dogbert asks for all of the jury award as his payment for winning the lawsuit.
Dilbert returns to his job and finds out he has a new cubicle.
Ted's position is eliminated. Ted complains his performance reviews have always been good.
Wally wants a raise or else he'll eat unhealthy food and avoid exercise.
Catbert says wellness programs pay off eventually but aren't good in the short term.
Catbert is concerned about job performance but won't supply an ergonomically correct chair.
Dogbert the financial baker is asked to cook the company books.
Dogbert cooks the books by assuming the pension plan will earn 15% per year.
Wally said he didn't have time to install critical updates and couldn't connect his computer to the Internet without the critical updates.
Dilbert is to get input from Allen, an amorphous cloud of gas.
The Boss is puzzled because his smartest employees keep disagreeing with him.
Alice is addicted to the online job posting system.
Alice talks to s psychiatrist about her addiction to looking at online job postings.
The Boss asks for a high-level view. Dilbert compares the situation like a bunch of termites eating a log.
The Boss says he never has enough information to make decisions, but is a good judge of character.
Dress code is relaxed to include shorts because the company uses less air conditioning to save money.
The Boss treats Dilbert as an idiot and explains obvious things.
The company is reevaluating their dress code that allows shorts, and covers Dilbert with a tarp.
The Boss asks Dilbert to find a photogenic hobo because the company wants to improve its image.
Dilbert meets with hobos to figure out to which one to give money.
Charitable giving by the company sparked a hobo riot.
Wally fits an entire presentation on one powerpoint slide. The entire slide is black.
Dilbert reports his laptop was stolen by Elbonian spies.
Asok signs up for a seminar on how to make a million dollars. The others insist it is a scam.
Elbonians look through the laptop stolen from Dilbert.
Wally reads a magazine about sitting. He wonders why they have an article on leaning.
Wally reports he spent the week focused on ergonomics and kept his guts moist.
Dilbert asks a company lawyer to turn a simple agreement into gibberish.
The company lawyer finishes a contact started during the Miocene era.
Alice says they should do something special for Shelly's birthday.
The Boss stops Wally from leaving work early.
The Boss asks a prospective employee if he will deliver bad news.
Instead of a raise, the Boss threatens Alice with a bad reference.
The Boss says they will adopt best practises, just like everyone else in the industry.
A ghost of a former employee introduces himself to Alice. The ghost used to do Alice's function.
A helpful ghost makes Alice look bad by comparison.
Catbert introduces a mandatory stretch period for the employees.
The Boss rejects a proposal from Dilbert because he needs to do his job to the max.
Ted got promoted so a collection is made to buy him a cake.
